citations.narrative:
There were approximately 3 - 5 containers of bleach being stored in plastic buckets in the chimpanzee food preparation
area. Spillage of toxic substances in food preparation areas represents a potential risk to the health and welfare of the
animals. At time of inspection there was no spillage observed.
Substances that are toxic to the non-human primates, but are required for normal husbandry practices, must not be stored
in food storage and preparation areas but may be stored in cabinets in the animal areas.
To be corrected by September 30, 2023

The following was observed in the back areas of the roundhouse cages of the lemurs, mangabey and mandrill primary
enclosures: At least 5 of the top supporting wood beams had visible dry rot with multiple holes and a soft pitted
appearance. In addition, the mandrill enclosure had peeling paint on all of the supporting beams which extended into the
interior of the cage. Primary enclosures in disrepair may represent increased risk of health hazards to the animals.
Primary enclosures for nonhuman primates must be structurally sound and kept in good repair to protect the health and
safety of the animals.
To be corrected by January 30, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Geoffrey Olsen, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.75(e) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
There were approximately 3 - 5 containers of bleach being stored in plastic buckets in the chimpanzee food preparation 
area. Spillage of toxic substances in food preparation areas represents a potential risk to the health and welfare of the 
animals. At time of inspection there was no spillage observed.  
Substances that are toxic to the non-human primates, but are required for normal husbandry practices, must not be stored 
in food storage and preparation areas but may be stored in cabinets in the animal areas. 
To be corrected by September 30, 2023 
3.80(a)(1) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The following was observed in the back areas of the roundhouse cages of the lemurs, mangabey and mandrill primary 
enclosures: At least 5 of the top supporting wood beams had visible dry rot with multiple holes and a soft pitted 
appearance. In addition, the mandrill enclosure had peeling paint on all of the supporting beams which extended into the 
interior of the cage. Primary enclosures in disrepair may represent increased risk of health hazards to the animals. 
Primary enclosures for nonhuman primates must be structurally sound and kept in good repair to protect the health and 
safety of the animals.  
To be corrected by January 30, 2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Geoffrey Olsen, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
